It was used just once, by the British character [[Kent Paul]] (voiced by [[Danny Dyer]]), who refers to [[Maccer]] as a "soppy cunt" in the mission ''Don Peyote.''[http://sabotagetimes.com/life/gta-v-the-10-greatest-characters-in-grand-theft-auto-history "GTA V & The 10 Greatest Characters In Grand Theft Auto History"], Matthew Cooper, Sep 10, 2013, Sabotage Times The 2004 title ''[[The Getaway: Black Monday]]'' by [[Sony Computer Entertainment|SCEE]] used the word several times during the game.[http://au.ign.com/articles/2004/11/30/the-getaway-black-monday "THE GETAWAY: BLACK MONDAY"], 30 Nov 2004, {{cite web |url=http://au.ign.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210224149/http://au.ign.com/ |archivedate=2014-12-10 |df= }} In the 2008 title ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' (developed by [[Rockstar North]] and distributed by [[Take Two Interactive]]), the word, amongst many other expletives, was used by James Pegorino who, after finding out that his personal bodyguard had [[Turn state's evidence|turned states]], exclaimed "The world is a cunt!" while aiming a shotgun at the player.{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/gaming/gamingreviews/news/2007/03/FF_160_rockstar?currentPage=all |title=The Road to Ruin: How Grand Theft Auto Hit the Skids |date=March 29, 2007 |accessdate=2008-06-17 |work=Wired |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505235747/http://www.wired.com/gaming/gamingreviews/news/2007/03/FF_160_rockstar/?currentPage=all |archivedate=May 5, 2008}} ===Other uses=== Popular singer, [[Rihanna]], has been outspoken about her use of the word "cunt". She was photographed in 2011 wearing a necklace spelling the word. She later explained why she uses it in an interview with [[Vogue (British magazine)|British ''Vogue'']]. The Barbados-born singer said she "never knew" that the word was offensive until she moved to the United States.{{Cite news|title = A Fascinating History of the "C Word"|url = http://www.alternet.org/gender/fascinating-history-c-word|newspaper = AlterNet|date = 2012-08-14|access-date = 2015-10-22|first = Lindsay|last = Zoladz}} ==Linguistic variants and derivatives== Various [[euphemism]]s, [[minced oath|minced]] forms and [[in-joke]]s are used to imply the word without actually saying it, thereby escaping obvious censure and censorship. ===Spoonerisms=== {{See also|Spoonerism}} Deriving from a [[dirty joke]]: "What's the difference between a circus and a strip club?"- "The circus has a bunch of cunning stunts...."{{cite journal |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/537724?uid=3739616&uid=2&uid=4&uid=3739256&sid=21102646211393 |last=Dundes |first= Alan |authorlink= |author2=Georges, Robert A. |date=September 1962 |title=Some Minor Genres of Obscene Folklore |journal=The Journal of American Folklore |volume=75 |issue=297 |pages=221–226 |doi=10.2307/537724 |publisher=American Folklore Society |jstor=537724 |accessdate=2013-09-13}} The phrase ''cunning stunt'' has been used in popular music. Its first documented appearance was by the English band [[Caravan (band)|Caravan]], who released the album ''[[Cunning Stunts (Caravan album)|Cunning Stunts]]'' in July 1975;{{cite web |url=http://www.caravan-info.co.uk/backcatalogue/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124212230/http://www.caravan-info.co.uk/backcatalogue/ |archivedate=2010-01-24 | title=Caravan discography |publisher=Caravan Information Service |date = September 2005|accessdate=2009-02-12}} the title was later used by [[Metallica]] for a [[Cunning Stunts (Metallica)|CD/Video compilation]], and in 1992 [[the Cows]] released an [[Cunning Stunts (Cows album)|album with the same title]]. In his 1980s BBC television programme, [[Kenny Everett]] played a vapid starlet, ''Cupid Stunt''.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/classic/kennyeverett/gallery/09.shtml |title=Classic TV – The Kenny Everett Television Show – Gallery |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2008-03-16}} ===Acronyms=== There are numerous informal acronyms, including various apocryphal stories concerning academic establishments, such as the ''Cambridge University [[National Trust]] Society''.{{cite web |url=http://standanddeliver.blogs.com/dombo/bill_oddie/index.html | title=My Chat with Graeme Garden, Full Blown |last=Romeo |first=Demetrius |date=22 February 2005 |accessdate=2009-02-12}} There are many variants of the covering phrase "[[wikt:see you next Tuesday|See you next Tuesday]]". Creative works with that phrase as a title include a play by [[Ronald Harwood]], [[See You Next Tuesday (album)|the second album]] by hip hop group FannyPack, [[See You Next Tuesday (film)|a 2013 independent film]] by Drew Tobia, a song by deathcore band The Acacia Strain on their 2006 album ''[[The Dead Walk (album)|The Dead Walk]]'', a song by Kesha from the 2010 EP ''[[Cannibal (EP)|Cannibal]]'', and [[See You Next Tuesday (band)|an experimental deathcore band]]. A more recent acronym is "Can't Use New Technology" which is thought to originate from IT staff.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} ===Puns=== The name "Mike Hunt" is a frequent pun on ''my cunt''; it has been used in a scene from the movie ''[[Porky's]]'',{{cite web | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0084522/quotes | title = Porky's (1982) | accessdate = 2008-03-18}} and for a character in the [[BBC]] radio comedy ''[[Radio Active (radio series)|Radio Active]]'' in the 1980s.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcomedy.org.uk/comedy/radioactive.htm|title=Radio Active|publisher=}} "Has Anyone Seen Mike Hunt?" were the words written on a "pink neon sculpture" representing the letter C, in a 2004 exhibition of the alphabet at the [[British Library]] in collaboration with the [[International Society of Typographic Designers]].{{cite web |title=Etymology Of Cunt |url=http://www.tanyapretorius.co.za/content/infoholism/etymology/etymology%20cunt.htm |last=Pretorius |first=Tanya |work=Tanya Pretorius' Bookmarks |accessdate=2009-02-12}}{{cite news|first=Maev | last=Kennedy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/oct/23/education.arts |title=Library show for word rhyming with hunt|publisher=Guardian |date= 2004-10-23|accessdate=2011-12-18 |location=London}} As well as obvious references, there are also allusions. On ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue]]'', [[Stephen Fry]] once defined ''countryside'' as the act of "murdering [[Piers Morgan]]".{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/des-kelly-my-life-in-media-519169.html | title = Des Kelly – My Life in Media | accessdate = 2008-04-06 | work=The Independent | location=London | date=2005-12-12}} Even Parliaments are not immune from punning uses; as recalled by former [[prime minister of Australia|Australian prime minister]] [[Gough Whitlam]]: {{quote|Never in the House did I use the word which comes to mind. The nearest I came to doing so was when [[Sir Winton Turnbull]], a member of the cavalleria rusticana, was raving and ranting on the adjournment and shouted: "I am a [[Australian Country Party (1920)|Country]] member". I interjected "I remember". He could not understand why, for the first time in all the years he had been speaking in the House, there was instant and loud applause from both sides.{{cite web|url=http://whitlamdismissal.com/speeches/00-05-24_politicians-humour-debate.shtml |title=That Politicians Have Lost Their Sense Of Humour |date=24 May 2000 |publisher=Whitlamdismissal.com |accessdate=2009-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129192011/http://whitlamdismissal.com/speeches/00-05-24_politicians-humour-debate.shtml |archivedate=29 January 2009 |df=}}}}and [[Mark Lamarr]] used a variation of this same gag on BBC TV's ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]''. "[[Stuart Adamson]] was a [[Big Country]] member... and we do remember".{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115286/quotes | title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks (1996) |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate =2009-02-12}} ===Rhyming slang=== Several celebrities have had their names used as euphemisms, including footballer [[Roger Hunt]],{{cite book|last=Partridge|first=Eric|author2=Tom Dalzell|author3=Terry Victor|title=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=New York|year=2006|isbn=0-415-25938-X}} actor [[Gareth Hunt]],{{cite web|url=http://www.peevish.co.uk/slang/g.htm |title=A dictionary of slang – "G" – Slang and colloquialisms of the UK|publisher=Peevish.co.uk|accessdate=2011-12-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cockneyrhymingslang.co.uk/slang/gareth_hunt|title=Gareth Hunt is rhyming slang|publisher=|accessdate=27 September 2014}}Anonymous ''Dirty Cockney Rhyming Slang'' Michael O'Mara Books Ltd. {{ISBN|1-84317-035-3}} singer [[James Blunt]], politician [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]],{{cite news|last=Watt|first=Holly|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/leveson-inquiry/9224722/Jeremy-Hunt-profile-rising-star-who-survived-expenses-scandal.html|title=Jeremy Hunt profile: rising star who survived expenses scandal|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=25 April 2012|accessdate=2013-09-13|location=London}} and 1970s motor-racing driver [[James Hunt]], whose name was once used to introduce the British radio show ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue]]'' as "the show that is to panel games what James Hunt is to rhyming slang". An old [[cant (language)|canting]] form is ''berk'', short for "[[Berkeley Hunt]]" or "Berkshire Hunt",{{cite web | url = http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/berk | title = Berk – Definition from the Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary | accessdate = 2008-04-06}}{{cite web | url = http://www.everything2.org/index.pl?node_id=99938 | title = Cockney rhyming slang@Everything2.com | accessdate = 2008-04-06}} and in a [[Monty Python]] sketch, an [[idioglossia]]c man replaces the initial "c" of words with "b", producing "silly bunt". Scottish comedian [[Chic Murray]] claimed to have worked for a firm called "Lunt, Hunt & Cunningham".{{cite web|url=http://www.transdiffusion.org/emc/tvheroes/haldaneduncan/chic_murray_remembered.php |title=TV Heroes: Part 09: Chic Murray Remembered |accessdate=2008-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080608032031/http://www.transdiffusion.org/emc/tvheroes/haldaneduncan/chic_murray_remembered.php |archivedate=2008-06-08 |df=}} ===Derived meanings=== The word "cunt" forms part of some technical terms used in seafaring and other industries. * In nautical usage, a '''cunt splice''' is a type of [[Rope splicing|rope splice]] used to join two lines in the [[rigging]] of ships.William Falconer, ''[http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-ss-refs-falc-1243 William Falconer's Dictionary of the Marine]'' (London: Thomas Cadell, 1780), 1243. Its name has been [[Thomas Bowdler|bowdlerised]] since at least 1861, and in more recent times it is commonly referred to as a "cut splice".Clifford W. Ashley, ''The Ashley Book of Knots'' (New York: Doubleday, 1944), 461. * The ''Dictionary of Sea Terms'', found within [[Richard Henry Dana, Jr.|Dana's]] 1841 maritime [[compendium]] ''The Seaman's Friend'', defines the word '''cuntline''' as "the space between the bilges of two casks, stowed side by side. Where one cask is set upon the cuntline between two others, they are stowed ''bilge and cuntline''."Richard Henry Dana, Jr., ''[http://www.hmssurprise.org/Resources/DanaSFLex.html The Seaman's Friend: A Treatise on Practical Seamanship, 14th Edition]'' (Boston: Thomas Groom & Co., 1879; Dover Republication 1997), 104. The "bilge" of a barrel or cask is the widest point, so when stored together the two casks would produce a curved V-shaped gap. The glossary of ''[[The Ashley Book of Knots]]'' by [[Clifford Ashley|Clifford W. Ashley]], first published in 1944, defines '''cuntlines''' as "the surface seams between the strands of a rope."Ashley, 598. Though referring to a different object from Dana's definition, it similarly describes the crease formed by two abutting cylinders.Examples of Ashley's usage of "cuntline" are found in the descriptions for illustrations #3338 and #3351. * In US military usage personnel refer privately to a common uniform item, a flat, soft cover (hat) with a fold along the top resembling an invagination, as a '''cunt cap'''.{{cite book |title= War Slang: American Fighting Words and Phrases Since the Civil War|last= Dickson|first= Paul|authorlink= |year= 2004|publisher= Brassey's|location= Dulles, Virginia|isbn= 978-1-57488-710-5|page= 145}} The proper name for the item is [[garrison cap]] or overseas cap, depending on the organization in which it is worn. * '''Cunt hair''' (sometimes as [[red cunt hair]]) has been used since the late 1950s to signify a very small distance. * '''Cunt-eyed''' has been used to refer to a person with narrow, squinting eyes.{{Cite book|title=Green's Dictionary of Slang|first=Jonathon |last=Green |volume=1 |publisher=Chambers |date=2008 |isbn=978-0550-10443-4|page=1456 |url= https://greensdictofslang.com/entry/w7hgqcy |accessdate=15 February 2018 |quote=... used of a person with narrow, squinting eyes}} ==See also== * [[Profanity]] * [[Scunthorpe problem]] * [[Seven dirty words]] * [[Sexual slang]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * ''Lady Love Your Cunt'', 1969 article by [[Germaine Greer]] (see ''References'' above) * ''Vaginal Aesthetics'', re-creating the representation, the richness and sweetness, of "vagina/cunt", an article by Joanna Frueh Source: ''Hypatia'', Vol. 18, No. 4, Women, Art, and Aesthetics (Autumn–Winter 2003), pp. 137–158 * {{cite web |first1=Eve |last1=Siebert |publisher=Sceptical Humanities |title=Chaucer's Cunt |url=http://skepticalhumanities.com/2011/01/18/chaucers-cunt/ |accessdate=February 28, 2014}} {{wiktionary}} {{commons category|Female genitalia}} {{Sexual slang}} [[Category:Misogynistic slurs]] [[Category:Pejorative terms for people]] [[Category:Profanity]] [[Category:English words]] [[Category:Sexual slang]] [[Category:Sexuality and gender-related slurs]] [[Category:Slang terms for women]] [[Category:Slang terms for men]] [[Category:Mammal female reproductive system]] [[Category:Vulva]]

{{distinguish|Embolism}} '''Ebullism''' is the formation of [[gas]] [[liquid bubble|bubble]]s in [[bodily fluids]] due to reduced environmental pressure, for example at high [[altitude]]. It occurs because a system of liquid and gas at equilibrium will see a net conversion of liquid to gas as pressure lowers, for example, liquids reach their boiling point at lower temperatures when the pressure on them is lowered.
==Description== In the atmospheric pressure present at [[sea level]], water boils at {{convert|100|°C}}. At an altitude of {{convert|63,000|feet}}, it boils at only {{convert|37|°C}}, the normal [[body temperature]] of humans. This altitude is known as ''[[Armstrong limit|Armstrong’s Line]].''<ref name="Fundamentals">Davis, Jeffrey R., Johnson, Robert, and Stepanek,Jan, ''Fundamentals of Aerospace Medicine'', 4th Edition (2008), p. 252.</ref> In practice bodily fluids do not boil off at this altitude. This is because the skin and outer organs have enough strength to withstand this pressure,<ref>Landis, Geoffrey A., "[http://www.geoffreylandis.com/vacuum.html Human Exposure to Vacuum] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721182306/http://www.geoffreylandis.com/vacuum.html |date=July 21, 2009 }}" (Retrieved 2010-02-16).</ref> thus pressure inside the body would be significantly higher—however, bubbles starting to form is still an issue.
==Symptoms== Symptoms of ebullism<ref>Czarnik, Tam, "[http://www.geoffreylandis.com/ebullism.html Ebullism at 1 Million Feet]" (Retrieved 2010-02-16).</ref> include bubbles in the membranes of the mouth and eyes, swelling of the [[skin]], and bubbles in the blood. Blood circulation and breathing may be impaired or stopped. The [[brain]] tissue may be [[Hypoxia (medical)|starved]] of [[oxygen]] because of blockage of [[artery|arteries]], and the [[lungs]] may swell and [[hemorrhage]]. Death results unless recompression is rapid enough to reduce the bubbles before tissue damage occurs.
In 1960, [[Joseph Kittinger]] experienced localised ebullism during a {{convert|31|km}} ascent in a [[helium]]-driven gondola.<ref name = Pilmanis2003>{{cite journal|last=Pilmanis|first=Andrew|author2=William Sears |title=Physiological hazards of flight at high altitude|journal=The Lancet|date=December 2003|volume=362|pages=s16–s17|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(03)15059-3|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673603150593}}</ref> His right-hand glove failed to pressurise and his hand expanded to roughly twice its normal volume<ref name="NYT May 24, 2008">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/24/sports/othersports/24jump.html|title=20-Year Journey for 15-Minute Fall|last=Higgins|first=Matt|date=May 24, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]] (online)|accessdate=2012-09-23|page=2}}</ref><ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/escape/skydive.html "Skydive from the Stratosphere"], ''NOVA Online'', [[Public Broadcasting Service]](PBS). November 2000. Retrieved 2012-09-23</ref> accompanied by disabling pain. His hand took about 3 hours to recover after his return to the ground.
==Prevention== To prevent ebullism, a pure oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) atmosphere was used in early space flights to eliminate nitrogen in the blood. There are major fire hazards associated with using pure O<sub>2</sub> as a breathing gas, which was central to the death of three astronauts in a fire during a ground test with [[Apollo 1]].<ref name="apollo1" /> Nonetheless NASA continued to use a [nominally] pure oxygen atmosphere throughout the Apollo Program but switched to air for the follow-on Space Transport System "Space Shuttle". Russian cosmonauts used pure oxygen before changing to a higher-pressure [[nitrox]] mixture, leading to incompatibility problems in 1975 on the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project.<ref name="spaceline" /> Space suits are often pressurized to several [[pounds per square inch|psi]] lower than stations' capsules or shuttles and since they still use pure O<sub>2</sub>, an acclimation period is common in the airlock to remove nitrogen and other gases from the bloodstream.
== See also == * [[Decompression sickness]] * [[Uncontrolled decompression]]
== References == {{reflist |refs= <ref name="apollo1">{{cite web |url=https://history.nasa.gov/Apollo204/|title=NASA Apollo Mission Apollo-1 |last=Garber |first=Steve |date=18 January 2007 |publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration |accessdate=16 February 2010}}</ref> <ref name="spaceline">{{cite web |url=http://www.spacearium.com/special/spaceline/spaceline.org/astp.html |title=Apollo-Soyuz Test Project |last=Lethbridge |first=Cliff |date=2000 |publisher=Spaceline |accessdate=16 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100120063424/http://www.spacearium.com/special/spaceline/spaceline.org/astp.html |archivedate=20 January 2010 |df= }}</ref> }}

{{NOTOC}} The '''Endangered Languages Archive''' (ELAR) is a [[digital archive]] for materials on [[endangered languages]], based at [[SOAS, University of London|SOAS University of London]]. The Archive preserves digital collections, including audio and video recordings, of endangered languages around the world. ELAR is part of the worldwide community of language archives ([http://www.delaman.org/ Delaman] and the [http://www.language-archives.org/ Open Language Archives Community])
== Archive == The collection currently contains over 400 deposits, the majority of which are the results of [https://www.eldp.net/ Endangered Languages Documentation Project] (ELDP) documentation projects<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eldp.net/|title=Endangered Languages Documentation Programme|last=|first=|date=|website=www.eldp.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-12-03}}</ref> which are funded by the [https://www.arcadiafund.org.uk/ Arcadia Fund]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arcadiafund.org.uk/|title=Arcadia - preserve endangered culture and nature|website=Arcadia Fund|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>.
The catalogue of archived materials can be freely searched via the [http://www.language-archives.org/archive/elar.soas.ac.uk Open Languages Archives Community.] The endangered languages collections at ELAR can be accessed free of charge.
== Affiliations == The archive was originally funded in 2002 as part of a donation to SOAS by the Arcadia Fund to support the documentation of endangered languages, to train students and scholars in language documentation and to digitally preserve and publish the collections.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SOAS’ Endangered Languages Documentation Programme receives a further $11 million from Arcadia {{!}} SOAS, University of London|url = https://www.soas.ac.uk/news/newsitem102002.html|website = www.soas.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref> Since 2015 ELAR is housed in and supported by the SOAS library.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eldp.net/en/what+we+do/|title=preserve endangered languages globally|website=www.eldp.net|accessdate=2015-12-03}}</ref> The ELAR office is in the SOAS main campus building near Russell Square. Since 2014 [[Mandana Seyfeddinipur]] is the head of the archive.<ref>{{Cite report| url = https://www.soas.ac.uk/elar/about-elar/reports/file110701.pdf| title = Annual Report 2014| page=22}}</ref>

{{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[20th-century philosophy|20th]] / [[21st-century philosophy]] |image = Presentación del Documental CATASTROIKA y Presentación de la Revista Debates y Combates (7215329954).jpg |caption = Ernesto Laclau in 2012 |name = Ernesto Laclau |birth_date = 6 October 1935 |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina |death_date = {{death date and age|2014|4|13|1935|10|6|df=y}} |death_place = [[Seville]], Spain |school_tradition = [[Post-Marxism]] |main_interests = [[Hegemony]]{{·}}[[Identity politics]] |notable_ideas = |influences = [[Karl Marx|Marx]]{{·}}[[Antonio Gramsci|Gramsci]]{{·}}[[Jorge Abelardo Ramos|Ramos]]{{·}}[[Louis Althusser|Althusser]]{{·}}[[Eric Hobsbawm|Hobsbawm]]{{·}}[[Jacques Lacan|Lacan]]{{·}}[[Michel Foucault|Foucault]]{{·}}[[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]]{{·}} [[Ludwig Wittgenstein|Wittgenstein]] |influenced = [[Slavoj Žižek|Žižek]]{{·}}[[Judith Butler|Butler]]{{·}}[[Simon Critchley|Critchley]]{{·}}[[Oliver Marchart|Marchart]]{{·}}[[Yannis Stavrakakis|Stavrakakis]]{{·}}[[Aletta Norval|Norval]]{{·}}[[Íñigo Errejón|Errejón]] }} '''Ernesto Laclau''' ({{IPA-es|laˈklau|lang}}; 6 October 1935 – 13 April 2014) was an Argentine [[political theory|political theorist]]. He is often described as an 'inventor' of [[Post-marxism|post-Marxist]] political theory. He is well known for his collaborations with his long-term partner, [[Chantal Mouffe]].
He studied History in Buenos Aires, graduating from the [[Universidad Nacional de Buenos Aires]] in 1964, and received a PhD from the [[University of Essex]] in 1977.
Since 1986 he served as Professor of Political Theory at the University of Essex, where he founded and directed for many years the graduate programme in [[Ideology]] and [[Discourse Analysis]], as well as the Centre for Theoretical Studies in the Humanities and the Social Sciences. Under his directorship, the Ideology and Discourse Analysis programme has provided a research framework for the development of a distinct type of discourse analysis that draws on post-structuralist theory (especially the work of [[Ferdinand de Saussure|Saussure]], and [[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]]), post analytic thought ([[Ludwig Wittgenstein|Wittgenstein]], and [[Richard Rorty]]) and psychoanalysis (primarily the work of [[Jacques Lacan|Lacan]]) to provide innovative analysis of concrete political phenomena, such as identities, discourses and hegemonies. This theoretical and analytical orientation is known today as the '[[Essex School of discourse analysis]]'.<ref>See Jules Townshend, 'Discourse theory and political analysis: a new paradigm from the Essex School?’, ''British Journal of Politics and International Relations'', Vol. 5, No. 1, February 2003, pp. 129–142.</ref>
Over his career Laclau lectured extensively in many universities in North America, South America, Western Europe, Australia, and South Africa. Most recently he has held positions at [[SUNY Buffalo]] and [[Northwestern University]], both in the US.
Laclau died of a [[heart attack]] in Seville in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rivadavia.com.ar/articulos/ultimo-momento-fallecio-en-sevilla-el-teorico-y-politologo-ernesto-laclau/ |title=ÚLTIMO MOMENTO: Falleció en Sevilla, el téorico y politólogo argentino, Ernesto Laclau | Radio Rivadavia |publisher=Rivadavia.com.ar |date= |accessdate=2014-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414130300/http://rivadavia.com.ar/articulos/ultimo-momento-fallecio-en-sevilla-el-teorico-y-politologo-ernesto-laclau/ |archivedate=2014-04-14 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Blackburn |first=Robin |url=http://www.versobooks.com/blogs/1556-ernesto-laclau-1935-2014 |title=Ernesto Laclau, 1935-2014 |publisher=VersoBooks.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-14}}</ref>
== Biography ==
Laclau studied History at the [[University of Buenos Aires]]<ref name="La Nacion">[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1680569-cuales-eran-las-principales-ideas-de-la-obra-de-ernesto-laclau Cuáles eran las principales ideas de la obra de Ernesto Laclau] - La Nacion, 13 April 2014</ref> and was a member of the [[National Left (Argentina)|PSIN]] (Socialist Party of the National Left) until 1969, when the British historian [[Eric Hobsbawm]] supported his entrance to Oxford.<ref name=P12>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/suplementos/radar/9-2286-2005-06-09.html Las manos en la masa - Ernesto Laclau contra Negri, Hardt y Zizek], ''[[Pagina/12]]'', June 5, 2005 {{es icon}}</ref> He had close links with [[Jorge Abelardo Ramos]], the founder of the PSIN, although he stated in 2005 that the latter had evolved in a direction he did not appreciate.<ref name=P12/> In the same interview, he claimed that he came from a [[Hipólito Yrigoyen|Yrigoyenista]] family, and that the Peronist politician [[Arturo Jauretche]], a strong opponent of [[Agustín Pedro Justo|Justo]]'s dictatorship during the [[Infamous Decade]] of the 1930s, was a close friend of his father.<ref name=P12/>
In his later years, he had close ties with the Argentine Socialist Confederation (Spanish: ''Confederación Socialista Argentina''),<ref>[http://www.lavanguardiaweb.com/detalle.php?a=una-apuesta-por-la-transformacion&t=30&d=203 Una apuesta por la transformación] - La Vanguardia</ref> and in Argentina he is associated with [[Peronism]].<ref>[http://noticias.perfil.com/2014-04-13-46955-ernesto-laclau-el-ideologo-de-la-argentina-dividida/ Ernesto Laclau, el ideólogo de la Argentina dividida] - Perfil, 14 April 2014</ref>
== Work ==
Laclau's early work was influenced by Althusserian Marxism and focused on issues debated within Neo-Marxist circles in the 1970s, such as the role of the state, the dynamics of capitalism, the importance of building popular movements, and the possibility of revolution. Laclau's most significant book is ''[[Hegemony and Socialist Strategy]]'', which he co-authored with [[Chantal Mouffe]] in 1985. The position outlined in this book is usually described as post-Marxist because it rejects (a) [[Marxism|Marxist]] [[economic determinism]] and (b) the view that [[class struggle]] is the most important antagonism in society. In their 2001 introduction to the second edition Laclau and Mouffe commented on this label, stating that whilst '''post''-Marxist' they were also 'post-''Marxist''<nowiki/>':<ref>{{Cite book|title = Hegemony and Socialist Strategy|last = Laclau|first = Erneso|publisher = Verso|year = 2001 |origyear=1985|isbn = |location = London|pages = }}</ref> their work, though a departure from traditional Western Marxism, retained similar concerns and ideas. A key innovation in ''Hegemony and Socialist Strategy'' was Laclau and Mouffe's argument that left-wing movements need to build alliances with a wide variety of different groups if they are to be successful and establish a left-wing 'hegemony'. In the final chapter of the book, the project of "radical and plural democracy" was advocated: a democracy in which subjects accept the importance of the values of liberty and equality, but fight over what the terms mean.
In ''Hegemony and Socialist Strategy'' Laclau and Mouffe also offered a constructivist account of 'discourse'. By drawing on the work of the later Wittgenstein, they argued that social entities only become meaningful through discursive articulation. As such, the meaning of something is never pre-given but is, instead, constructed through social practices. Laclau subsequently used this account of discourse to re-consider the nature of identity, arguing that all political identities are discursive - even if they are experienced by individuals as 'natural' (even to the point where one's identity is not recognised as an identity). For example, though an individual may think that they are just 'born male' this is, for Laclau, not the case: 'maleness' is a socially constructed category that has no innate meaning.
In his more recent works Laclau returned to a topic that was prevalent in his earliest writings: populism. In ''On Populist Reason'', Laclau considered the nature of populism in political discourse, the creation of a popular hegemonic bloc such as "the people", and the importance of affect in politics. Building on his earlier work, Laclau argued that the basis of populism lies in the creation of "empty signifiers": words and ideas that express a universal idea of justice, and symbolically structure the political environment. Against those who see populism as a threat to democracy, Laclau argued that it is an essential component of it.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = On Populist Reason|last = Laclau|first = Ernesto|publisher = Verso|year = 2005|isbn = |location = London|pages = 232}}</ref>
=== Laclau's relationship with Slavoj Žižek === Laclau is known for his long standing dialogue with Lacanian 'arch-Marxist' [[Slavoj Žižek]]. This dates back to at least 1989, when Laclau wrote the introduction to Žižek's first book in English (''The Sublime Object of Ideology''). Žižek is widely recognized as responsible for Laclau's increased acceptance of Lacanian ideas, and his essay 'Beyond Discourse Analysis',<ref>{{Cite book|title = Beyond Discourse Analysis|last = Žižek|first = Slavoj|publisher = Verso|year = 1990|isbn = |location = London|pages = 249–260}}</ref> which was published in Laclau's ''New Reflections on the Revolutions of Our Time'' (1990), provided a psychoanalytic critique of Laclau's work. In 2000 Laclau, Žižek, and Judith Butler published the trialogue ''Contingency, Hegemony, Universality'', in which each responded to the others' works in a three-essay cycle. Though Žižek and Laclau noted their similarities and mutual respect, significant political and theoretical differences emerged between all three interlocutors. Following several acrimonious publications in the early 2000s Laclau wrote in 2005's ''On Populist Reason'' that Žižek had an impractical and confused approach to politics, describing him as 'waiting for the martians'.<ref name=":0" /> Their disagreement escalated in the pages of ''Critical Inquiry'' in 2006 where, in a spate of essays, the two argued in an increasingly hostile manner about political action, Marxism and class struggle, Hegel, populism, and the Lacanian Real.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 10.1086/508086|title = Why Constructing A People is the Main Task of Radical Politics|last = Laclau|first = Ernesto|date = 2006|journal = Critical Inquiry|doi = |pmid = }}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|jstor = 10.1086/509751|title = Schlagend, aber nicht Treffend!|last = Žižek|first = Slavoj|date = 2006|journal = Critical Inquiry|doi = |pmid = }}</ref><ref name=":1" /> More recently, in a 2014 interview with David Howarth, Laclau stated that his relationship with Žižek had deteriorated due to the latter adopting a 'frantic ultra-Leftist stance, wrapped in a Leninism of kindergarten'.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Ernesto Laclau: Post-Marxism, Populism and Critique|last = Laclau|first = Ernesto|publisher = Routledge|year = 2014|isbn = |location = Abingdon|pages = 271}}</ref>

{{use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{distinguish|Fact checker}} '''Fact-finding''' is the job of a person or group of persons in a judicial or administrative proceeding that has or have the responsibility of determining the facts relevant to decide a controversy. The term '''[[trier of fact]]''' generally denotes the same function.[http://www.answers.com/topic/fact-finding Law Dictionary: Fact-Finder]. Accessed 17 November 2008. The process is an extremely important part of the communication process.[http://www.colorado.edu/conflict/peace/problem/factfinding.htm General Information on Fact-Finding]. Colorado University. Accessed 17 November 2008. ==History== Fact-finding was first established during the [[Hague Convention of 1907]], which dealt with international commissions of inquiry.{{cite book | last = Ramcharan | first = B. G. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = International Law and Fact-finding in the Field of Human Rights | publisher = Martinus Nijhoff Publishers | year = 1983 | location = | pages = VII | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ytQL2DIF3VgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=fact+finding&client=firefox-a&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0#PPR7,M1 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-90-247-3042-1}} ===Declaration on Fact-finding by the United Nations=== On 9 December 1991, the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] of the [[United Nations]] approved the ''[[Declaration on Fact-finding by the United Nations in the Field of the Maintenance of International Peace and Security]]''. The resolution emphasized
...that the ability of the United Nations to maintain international peace and security depends to a large extent on its acquiring detailed knowledge about the factual circumstances of any dispute or situation.
and
to encourage States to bear in mind the role that competent organs of the United Nations can play in ascertaining the facts in relation to disputes or situations.United Nations. [https://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/46/a46r059.htm Declaration on Fact-finding by the United Nations in the Field of the Maintenance of International Peace and Security]. 9 December 1991. Accessed 17 November 2008.
There is also a range of fact-finding procedures in the [[United Nations]] relating to serious violations of human rights and humanitarian law, as well as fact-finding on the crimes of aggression, genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity which is carried out by the [[International Criminal Court]]. Professor [[Lyal S. Sunga]] discusses how UN human rights special procedures fact-finding can help the International Criminal Court find facts and how the two should be made complementary.[[Lyal S. Sunga]], "How Can UN Human Rights Special Procedures Sharpen ICC Fact-Finding?" 15(2) ''The International Journal of Human Rights'' (2011) 187–204. ==Triers of fact== {{main article|Trier of fact}} Fact finders often have the job of determining what facts are available and their relevancy.Schultz, Norman. [http://www.beyondintractability.org/essay/fact-finding/ Fact-Finding]. Accessed 17 November 2008 The position of fact finder is determined by the type of proceeding. In a jury trial, it is the role of a jury in a jury trial. In a non-jury trial, the judge sits both as a fact-finder and as the trier of law. In administrative proceedings it may be a hearing officer or a hearing body. ==Characteristics of fact-finding== According to the United Nations, fact-finding should be comprehensive, [[Journalistic objectivity|objective]], [[impartiality|impartial]] and [[timeliness|timely]].{{cite web |title=Resolution 46/59 Declaration of fact-finding missions |url=http://undocs.org/A/RES/46/59 |publisher=UN |location =New York |date=9 December 1991 |quote=Fact-finding should be comprehensive, objective, impartial and timely.}} ==See also== * [[UN fact-finding missions]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://legal.un.org/avl/ha/ga_46-59/ga_46-59.html Procedural history, related documents and photos] on the ''Declaration on Fact-finding by the United Nations in the Field of the Maintenance of International Peace and Security'' in the [http://legal.un.org/avl/historicarchives.html Historic Archives of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law] [[Category:Legal terminology]] [[Category:Research]] [[Category:Evidence law]]

{{About|the Greenlandic Norse language|the Greenlandic Norse people of Norwegian ancestry|Greenlandic Norse people}} {{Infobox Language |name=Greenlandic Norse |ethnicity= [[Greenlandic Norse people]] |region=[[Greenland]]; [[Western Settlement]] and [[Eastern Settlement]] |extinct=by the late 15th century or the early 16th century |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Germanic languages|Germanic]] |fam3=[[North Germanic languages|North Germanic]] |fam4=[[Old West Norse|West Scandinavian]] |fam5=Insular Scandinavian |ancestor=[[Old Norse]] |ancestor2=[[Old West Norse]] |iso3=none |glotto=none }} {{Old Norse topics}}
'''Greenlandic Norse''' is an extinct [[North Germanic languages|North Germanic language]] that was spoken in the Norse settlements of [[Greenland]] until their demise in the late 15th century. The language is attested through some 80 [[runic inscriptions]], many of which are difficult to date and not all of which were necessarily carved by people born in Greenland.<ref name='Bandle'>Bandle, p. 1234.</ref>
It is difficult to identify specifically Greenlandic linguistic features in the limited runic material. Nevertheless, there are inscriptions showing the use of ''t'' for historical ''[[þ]]'' in words such as ''torir'' rather than ''þorir'' and ''tana'' rather than ''þana''. This linguistic innovation has parallels in West Norwegian in the [[late Middle Ages|late medieval period]].<ref name='Bandle'/> On the other hand, Greenlandic appears to have retained some features which changed in other types of Scandinavian. This includes initial ''hl'' and ''hr'', otherwise only preserved in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]], and the long vowel ''œ'', which merged with ''æ'' in Icelandic but was preserved in [[Old Norwegian|Norwegian]].<ref>Barnes, p. 185.</ref>
Greenlandic Norse is believed to have been in [[language contact]] with [[Greenlandic language|Greenlandic]], the language of the indigenous [[Kalaallit]], and to have left [[loanword]]s in that language. In particular, the Greenlandic word ''Kalaaleq'' (older ''Karaaleq''), meaning ''Greenlander'', is believed to be derived from the word ''[[Skræling]]r'', the Norse term for the people they [[Norse colonization of the Americas|encountered in North America]].<ref>Jahr, p. 233.</ref> It has also been suggested that the word ''kona'', meaning ''woman'', is of Norse origin.<ref>Jahr, p. 231.</ref>
The available evidence does not establish the presence of [[language attrition]]; the language most likely disappeared with the ethnic group that spoke it.<ref name='Bandle'/>
A main characteristic of Greenlandic Norse was that it was very conservative. The older forms of speaking, which had come from Iceland and Norway, were kept intact. In keeping with this conservatism, the Greenlanders likewise maintained the older runic characteristics, most of which had fallen out of use in other countries. Notwithstanding this, they created new designs for the ð-, b-, p- and r-runes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arild-hauge.com/egronrun.htm|title=THE RUNES OF GREENLAND|last=Hauge|first=Arild|date=|website=www.arild-hauge.com|publisher=July 13, 2004|access-date=September 12, 2016}}</ref>
==Sample text== The [[Kingittorsuaq Runestone]] dates from c. 1300, discovered near [[Upernavik]], far north of the Norse settlements. It was presumably carved by Norse explorers. {| |'''Transcription''' |'''English translation''' | |- | : :el=likr * sikuaþs : so=n:r * ok * baan=ne : torta=r son : :ok enriþi * os son : laukardak*in : fyrir * gakndag :hloþu * ua=rda te * ok rydu :<ref>The [[Rundata]] database, downloaded and accessed on January 12, 2008.</ref> | : :Ellikr Sikuaþssonr and Baanne Tortarson :and Enriþi Osson, the Saturday before [[Rogation Sunday]] :made these stone cairns and cleared(?) | |} [[File:Runesten fra Kingittorsuaq.jpg|thumb|327x327px|The Kingittorsuaq Runestone]] The patronymic ''Tortarson'' ([[Old Norse orthography#Normalized spelling|standardized Old Norse]]: ''Þórðarson'') shows the change from ''þ'' to ''t'' while the word ''hloþu'' (Old Icelandic ''hlóðu'', Old Norwegian ''lóðu'') shows the retention of initial ''hl''.

In [[United States]] [[military terminology]], a '''high-value target''' ('''HVT''') is a person or resource that an enemy commander requires to complete a mission. The term has been widely used in the [[news media]] for [[Osama Bin Laden]] and high-ranking officers of [[Al-Qaeda]] who are considered essential for completing their operations. Former Iraqi President [[Saddam Hussein]] was known as High Value Target Number One by the United States military before [[Operation Red Dawn|his capture]].
Soldiers are often asked to do all that is possible to capture an HVT alive but, if that is impossible, they are given clearance to fire.{{cn|date=April 2018}} Various tasked Joint Special Operations Task Forces ([[Task Force 145]], [[Task Force 121]], [[Task Force 11]]) have been established for the main purposes of capturing or killing these high-value targets. Forces assigned to these tasked forces include units mainly from the [[Joint Special Operations Command ]] and [[United States Special Operations Command|SOCOM]] such as the US Navy SEALs, US Army [[Delta Force]], US Navy [[SEAL Team Six]], US Army [[75th Ranger Regiment (United States)|75th Ranger Regiment]] and elements of the [[British Army]]'s [[Special Air Service]] (SAS).<ref>Seymour M. Hersh, ''Moving Targets'', New Yorker, December 15, 2003 accessed at [http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2003/12/15/031215fa_fact?printable=true] on 13 Feb 2008</ref> The term has also become associated with secret [[US DoD]] programs to capture and interrogate terrorist leaders.<ref>Seymour M. Hersh, ''The Gray Zone:How a secret Pentagon program came to Abu Ghraib'', New Yorker, May 24, 2004 accessed at [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/05/24/the-gray-zone]</ref>

The loss of HVTs would be expected to seriously degrade important enemy functions throughout the friendly commander’s area of interest. See also high-payoff target; target. (JP 3-09) *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/09/AR2006090901105.html Bin Laden Trail 'Stone Cold'] [[Washington Post]] September 10, 2006
[[Category:Targeting (warfare)]] [[Category:Intelligence operations by type]] [[Category:Military terminology]] [[Category:Operations involving special forces]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Jizhao |nativename= |states=[[People's Republic of China]] |region=[[Guangdong]] |speakers= < 100 |date= 2017 |ref = <ref name="Li2017"/> |familycolor=Tai–Kadai |fam1=[[Kra–Dai languages|Kra–Dai]] |fam2=[[Be language|Be]]?<ref name="Ostapirat1998"/> |iso3= |glotto= |glottorefname= }} '''Jizhao''' ({{zh|吉兆话}}) is an unclassified [[Kra-Dai language]] spoken in Jizhao Village 吉兆村, Tanba Town 覃巴镇, [[Wuchuan, Guangdong]]. It may be most closely related to [[Be language|Be]].<ref name="Ostapirat1998"/> In Wuchuan, Jizhao is locally referred to as '''Haihua 海话''', which is the term used elsewhere in [[Leizhou]] 雷州, [[Xuwen]] 徐闻, and [[Maoming]] 茂名 to refer to the local [[Southern Min|Minnan Chinese]] dialect of Leizhou.<ref name="Shao2016">Shao Lanzhu [邵兰珠]; Meng Yuanyao [蒙元耀]. 2016. "Loanwords of Min dialect in Jizhao dialect in Guangdong" [广东吉兆话中的闽方言借词]. In ''Journal of Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology'' [广东石油化工学院学报], Vol. 26, No. 2, April 2016.</ref>
==Demographics== Jizhao is a highly endangered language that only has speakers above the age of 60 (Shao 2016:70). Within Jizhao Administrative Village 吉兆行政村, it is spoken in the hamlets (natural villages) of Jizhao 吉兆, Meilou 梅楼, and Hong 洪村 villages (Shao 2016:9).
As of 2017, there are fewer than 100 speakers of Jizhao, most of whom are above the age of 70.<ref name="Li2017">Li Jinfang [李锦芳]; Wu Yan [吴艳]. 2017. "[http://www.nssd.org/articles/article_detail.aspx?id=673048910 Guangdong Wuchuan Jizhaohua gaikuang]" [广东吴川吉兆话概况]. In ''Minzu Yuwen'' [民族语文] 2017:4.</ref>
==Classification== Shao & Meng (2016) observe some similarities with the [[Ong Be language|Be language]] of northern [[Hainan]], but provisionally consider Jizhao to be unclassified within the Kam-Tai (壮侗) branch. Jizhao has many loanwords from [[Yue Chinese]] and [[Southern Min|Minnan Chinese]].
Weera Ostapirat (1998),<ref name="Ostapirat1998">Ostapirat, W. (1998). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/23756759 A Mainland Bê Language? / 大陆的Bê语言？]. ''Journal of Chinese Linguistics'', 26(2), 338-344</ref> analyzing data from Zhang (1992)<ref name="Zhang1992">Zhang Zhenxing [张振兴]. 1992. "Guangdongsheng Wuchuan fangyan jilve" [广东省吴川方言记略]. In ''Fangyan'' [方言] 1992(3).</ref>, notes that Be and Jizhao share many lexical similarities and sound correspondences, and that Jizhao may be a remnant Be-related language on the Chinese mainland.
In a 100-item [[Swadesh list]], Shao (2016) found lexical matches between Jizhao and the following languages. *[[Ong Be language|Ong Be]]: 56 words *[[Zhuang languages|Zhuang]]: 6 words *[[Yue Chinese]]: 7 words *[[Min Chinese]]: 1 word *No parallels: 30 words
==Phonology== Jizhao has 6 tones (Shao 2016:15). #[21] #[31] #[32] #[33] #[55] #[45]
Jizhao, like [[Hlai language|Hlai]], also has the [[implosive consonant]]s /[[ɓ]]/ and /[[ɗ]]/ (Li & Wu 2017).
==See also== *[[Wiktionary:Appendix:Jizhao Swadesh list|Jizhao Swadesh list]] (Wiktionary)
==References== {{reflist}} *Li Jian [李健]. 2011. [https://wenku.baidu.com/view/28801ad9240c844769eaeef5.html?fr=zhidao 广东吴川吉兆海话的四种语音成分]. In 湛江师范学院学报. *Li Jinfang [李锦芳]; Wu Yan [吴艳]. 2017. "[http://www.nssd.org/articles/article_detail.aspx?id=673048910 Guangdong Wuchuan Jizhaohua gaikuang]" [广东吴川吉兆话概况]. In ''Minzu Yuwen'' [民族语文] 2017:4. *Shao Lanzhu [邵兰珠]. 2016. ''Guangdong Jizhaohua yanjiu'' [广东吉兆话研究]. M.A. dissertation: Guangxi University for Nationalities [广西民族大学]. *Shao Lanzhu [邵兰珠]; Meng Yuanyao [蒙元耀]. 2016. "Loanwords of Min dialect in Jizhao dialect in Guangdong" [广东吉兆话中的闽方言借词]. In ''Journal of Guangdong University of Petrochemical Technology'' [广东石油化工学院学报], Vol. 26, No. 2, April 2016. *Zhang Zhenxing [张振兴]. 1992. "Guangdongsheng Wuchuan fangyan jilve" [广东省吴川方言记略]. In ''Fangyan'' [方言] 1992(3).
==External links== *[http://news.gdzjdaily.com.cn/zjxw/content/2010-08/01/content_1237842.shtml 奇特的吴川吉兆话] *[http://wxy.gxun.edu.cn/info/1224/2008.htm 李锦芳教授：“濒危语言吉兆话研究” ]

'''José Aragón Escacena''' (born 1891 in [[Astorga, Spain|Astorga]], ([[León Province]]), [[Restoration (Spain)|Spain]]; died 1945 in [[Francoist Spain|Spain]]) was a [[Leonese language]] writer.
He wrote "''Entre Brumas''", edited in 1921 and awarded in the IX Century of Leonese "''Fueros''" (Laws).
== Books ==
* Entre Brumas (1921)
== See also == * [[List of Leonese language writers]] * [[Leonese language]] * [[Kingdom of León]]
==External links== * {{webarchive |date=2012-07-30 |url=https://archive.is/2012.07.30/http://www.eltoralin.com |title=Leonese language association from El Bierzu, in Leonese language}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090318174242/http://www.puntulli.org/ Top Level Domain for Leonese language, in Leonese language, English, Spanish, French, Italian and so oder]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aragon Escacena, Jose}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:People from Astorga, Spain]] [[Category:Leonese-language writers]]

{{about|the greeting}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{external media | align = right | width = 180px | audio1 = [http://www.tetaurawhiri.govt.nz/assets/Lions-Tour/Kia-ora.mp3 Pronunciation] at Kōrero Māori, the Māori Language Commission website }} '''Kia ora''' ({{IPA-mi|kia ora|lang}}, approximated in English as {{IPAc-en|ˌ|k|iː|ə|_|ˈ|ɔːr|ə}} {{respell|KEE|ə|_|OR|ə}}) is a [[Māori language]] [[greeting]] which has entered [[New Zealand English]]. It means, literally, ''have life'' ''be well/healthy'' and is translated as an informal ''hi'' or "hello" at the [[Māori Language Commission]] website Kōrero Māori.
==Uses== It might be used as a [[salutation]], a farewell or an expression of thanks.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.korero.maori.nz/forlearners/protocols/geetings.html |title=Ngā Mihi – Greetings |publisher=Kōrero Māori |accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref> It also signifies agreement with a speaker at a meeting, as part of a culture which prizes [[public speaking|oratory]]. These other Māori greetings, ''tēnā koe''; ''tēnā kōrua''; and ''tēnā koutou'' (respectively, one; two; and three or more people), are also widely used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.korero.maori.nz/forlearners/protocols/geetings.html|title=Ngā Mihi – Greetings |publisher=Kōrero Māori|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref> The [[Ministry for Culture and Heritage|New Zealand Ministry for Culture and Heritage]] website NZ History lists it as one of 100 Māori words every New Zealander should know, with a definition "Hi!, G'day! (general informal greeting)".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/culture/maori-language-week/100-maori-words#greeting |title=100 Maori words every New Zealander should know |publisher=[[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]] |accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
''Kia ora'' can follow a similar pattern to address different specific numbers of people. By itself, it can be used to address any number of people, but by adding ''koe'' (i.e., ''kia ora koe''); ''kōrua''; and ''koutou'' one can specify a greeting to, respectively, a single; two; or three or more people). Similarly, by following with ''tātou'', one addresses all the people present, including the speaker themselves.<ref>{{cite web|title=100 Māori words every New Zealander should know|url=https://nzhistory.govt.nz/culture/maori-language-week/100-maori-words|publisher=[[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]]|accessdate=27 May 2018}}</ref>
===Commercial=== New Zealand's national airline, [[Air New Zealand]], uses ''Kia Ora'' as the name for its [[inflight magazine]].<ref>{{cite web |title=KiaOra Air New Zealand inflight magazine |url= http://www.bauermedia.co.nz/Magazines/kiaora-air-new-zealand-inflight-magazine.htm |publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]] |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> Water Safety New Zealand, a [[water safety]] advocacy organisation, has a specific Maori water safety programme, ''Kia Maanu Kia Ora'', which makes use of the literal meaning of kia ora, as their message translates as ''stay afloat; stay alive''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Maori |url= http://www.watersafety.org.nz/education/maori/ |publisher=Water Safety New Zealand |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
==Controversy== In 1984, at a time when the use of Māori phrases was uncommon in New Zealand, an Auckland telephone operator, [[Naida Glavish]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://e-tangata.co.nz/news/naida-glavish-she-wouldnt-comply|title=Naida Glavish – she wouldn’t comply|date=6 September 2015|work=E-Tangata – A Māori and Pasifika Sunday magazine|access-date=19 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> was instructed to stop using ''kia ora'' when greeting callers after the post office had received a complaint. She refused to do so and was consequently stood down, with the whole affair attracting much public interest. The Postmaster-General, [[Rob Talbot]], convinced the [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Prime Minister]], [[Robert Muldoon]], to overturn that prohibition.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/timaru-herald/news/8115292/Rob-Talbot-dies-top-advocate-for-Sth-Canty | title= Rob Talbot dies, top advocate for Sth Canty | date=22 December 2012 | work=[[The Timaru Herald]] | accessdate=15 March 2015 | first=Mike | last=Crean}}</ref>
==Elsewhere== ''Kia ora'' has a similar meaning to the word ''kia orana'', found in related [[Polynesian languages]], such as [[Cook Islands Māori]].<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.cookislands.org.uk/raro1.html |title=Rarotonga |publisher=The Cook Islands website |accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|New Zealand}} * [[Aloha]] * [[wikt:g'day|g'day]] * [[List of English words of Māori origin]] * [[Māori influence on New Zealand English]] * [[Talofa]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kia Ora}} [[Category:Māori words and phrases]] [[Category:Greeting words and phrases]]

{{Infobox language |name=Kuot |altname= Panaris |states=[[Papua New Guinea]] |region=[[New Ireland Province|New Ireland]] |speakers=2,400 |date=2002 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Papuan |family=[[Language isolate]] |script=Latin |iso3=kto |glotto=kuot1243 |glottorefname=Kuot |notice=IPA }}
The '''Kuot language''', or '''Panaras''', is a [[language isolate]], the only non-[[Austronesian languages|Austronesian]] language spoken on the island of [[New Ireland (island)|New Ireland]], [[Papua New Guinea]]. There are about 2,400 speakers, concentrated primarily on the northwest coast of the island. Perhaps due to the small speaker base, there are no significant dialects present within Kuot.<ref>Chung, Chul-Hwa & Chung, Kyung-Ja, [http://www.sil.org/pacific/png/abstract.asp?id=37101 Kuot Grammar Essentials], 1993:p1</ref>
==Status== Kuot is an [[endangered language]] with most if not all children growing up speaking [[Tok Pisin]] instead.<ref>Eva Lindström (November 12, 2002). "Kuot Language and Culture". Department of Linguistics, Stockholm University. Retrieved October 14, 2016. p. 102.</ref>
==Phonology==
===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" | ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- ! colspan=2|[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA|m}} | {{IPA|n~ɲ}} | {{IPA|ŋ}} |- ! rowspan=2|[[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] !<small>voiceless</small> | {{IPA|p}} | {{IPA|t}} | {{IPA|k}} |- ! <small>voiced</small> | {{IPA|b}} | {{IPA|d}} | {{IPA|ɡ}} |- ! rowspan=2|[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! <small>voiceless</small> | {{IPA|ɸ~f}} | {{IPA|s~ʃ}} | |- ! <small>voiced</small> | {{IPA|β~v}} | | |- ! colspan=2|[[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | {{IPA|l}} | |- ! colspan=2|[[Flap consonant|Flap]] | | {{IPA|ɾ}} | |}
===Vowels===
The vowels /i/ and /u/ tend to become glide-vowels in occurrence with other vowels. The length of the vowels is not making differences for the meaning of words. The appearance of /i/ and /u/ with other vowels can not be seen as [[diphthong]] or a combination of vowel and glide-vowel. There are never more than three vowels per syllable. The combination of diphthong and vowel is also possible but they are pronounced in conditions of the syllable. Diphthongs are spoken like one sound.<ref>Eva Lindström (November 12, 2002). "Kuot Language and Culture". Department of Linguistics, Stockholm University. Retrieved October 14, 2016. p. 102.</ref>
{|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan=1| ! colspan=1|[[Front vowel|Front]] ! colspan=1|[[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA|i}} | {{IPA|u}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|e}} | {{IPA|o}} |- ![[Open vowel|Open]] | {{IPA|a}} | |}
====Allophones==== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan=1|[[Phoneme]] ! colspan=1|[[Allophones]] |- | {{IPA|/i/}} | {{IPA|[i~ɪ~j]}} |- | {{IPA|/e/}} | {{IPA|[e~ɛ]}} |- | {{IPA|/a/}} | {{IPA|[a~ʌ]}} |- | {{IPA|/u/}} | {{IPA|[u~ʊ~w]}} |- | {{IPA|/o/}} | {{IPA|[o~ɔ]}} |}
===Morphophonemic Alternations===
===='t' to 'r' Alternation====
The phoneme {{IPA|/t/}} in certain possessive markers, such as "''-tuaŋ''", "''-tuŋ''" and "''-tuo''" becomes {{IPA|/r/}} when it comes after a stem ending in a vowel. Compare:
* ''ira-ruaŋ'' – my father * ''luguan-tuaŋ'' – my house * ''i'rama-ruo'' – my eye * ''nebam-tuaŋ'' – my feather
====Vowel Shortening====
Where the third person singular masculine suffix "-oŋ" is used on a noun that ends with a vowel, this vowel is typically not pronounced. For instance, "''amaŋa-oŋ''" is pronounced {{IPA|[aˈmaŋɔŋ]}}, not {{IPA|[aˈmaŋaɔŋ]}}.
====Voicing Rule====
When vowel-initial suffixes are added to stems that end in voiceless consonants, those consonants become voiced. For example:
* {{IPA|/obareit-oŋ/}} {{IPA|[obaˈreidoŋ]}} ''he splits it'' * {{IPA|/taɸ-o/}} {{IPA|[taˈβo]}} ''he drinks'' * {{IPA|/marik-oŋ/}} {{IPA|[maˈriɡoŋ]}} ''he prays''
The phoneme {{IPA|/p/}} becomes {{IPA|[β]}}, not {{IPA|[b]}}.
* {{IPA|/sip-oŋ/}} {{IPA|[ˈsiβɔŋ]}} ''it comes out'' * {{IPA|/irap-a/}} {{IPA|[iˈraβa]}} ''her eyes''
==Grammar== The language uses a VSO word order, similar to [[Irish language|Irish]] and [[Welsh language|Welsh]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.ling.su.se/staff/evali/kuot.htm |title=Kuot Language and Culture |author=Eva Lindström |date=November 12, 2002 |publisher=Department of Linguistics, Stockholm University |accessdate=July 11, 2011}}</ref> The [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] of the language is primarily [[agglutinative]]. There are two grammatical genders, male and female, and distinction is made in the first person between singular, dual, and plural, as well as between exclusive and inclusive.
For instance, the sentence {{lang|kto|parak-oŋ ira-ruaŋ kamin}} literally means 'my father eats sweet potato'. ''Parak-oŋ'' is a [[continuous aspect]] of the verb meaning 'to eat', ''ira'' means 'father', ''-ruaŋ'' is a suffix used to indicate [[inalienable possession]] ('my father'), and ''kamin'' is a simple noun meaning '[[sweet potato]]'.
==See also== * [[East Papuan languages]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www2.ling.su.se/staff/evali/swadesh100-Kuot.html Kuot Swadesh 100 Word List]
{{Languages of Papua New Guinea}} {{language families}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kuot Language}} [[Category:Agglutinative languages]] [[Category:East Papuan languages]] [[Category:Language isolates of New Guinea]] [[Category:Languages of New Ireland Province]] [[Category:Verb–subject–object languages]] [[Category:Endangered Papuan languages]] [[Category:Endangered language isolates]]

There are at least forty languages spoken or used in [[Venezuela]],<ref>Ethnologue. [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=VE Languages of Venezuela].</ref> but [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is the language spoken by the majority of Venezuelans. The 1999 [[Constitution of Venezuela]] declared Spanish and languages spoken by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous people from Venezuela]] as official languages. Deaf people use [[Venezuelan Sign Language]] (''lengua de señas venezolana, LSV)''.
[[Chinese language|Chinese]] (400,000), [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (254,000)<ref name="Ethnologue"></ref> and [[Italian language|Italian]] (200,000),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bernasconi|first1=Giulia|title=L’ITALIANO IN VENEZUELA|journal=Italiano LinguaDue|date=2012|issue=2|page=20|doi=10.13130/2037-3597/1921|url=https://www.openaire.eu/search/publication?articleId=doajarticles::e2c6e2d8ae5915079007d321c21defb0|accessdate=22 January 2017|publisher=Università degli Studi di Milano|language=Italian|quote=L'italiano come lingua acquisita o riacquisita è largamente diffuso in Venezuela: recenti studi stimano circa 200.000 studenti di italiano nel Paese}}</ref> are the most spoken languages in Venezuela after the official language of Spanish. [[Wayuu language|Wayuu]] is the most spoken indigenous language with 170,000 speakers.<ref name="Ethnologue"></ref>
== Spanish language ==
Spanish is one of the official languages in Venezuela
== Indigenous languages ==
Below is a non-exhaustive list of these languages.
* [[Wayuu language|Wayuu]] * [[Warao language|Warao]] * [[Pemon language|Pemon]] * [[Mapoyo language|Mapoyo]] * [[Panare]] * [[Puinave language|Puinave]] * [[Pémono language|Pémono]] * [[Sapé language|Sapé]] * [[Sikiana language|Sikiana]] * [[Yabarana language|Yabarana]] * [[Yaruro language|Yaruro]]
Native language of Venezuela by number of speakers:
{| class="wikitable sortable zebra" |- style="background:aqua;color:black;" | '''Language''' | '''Family''' | '''Speakers in Venezuela''' | '''Latest ISO Code''' |- align=center | [[Piapoco language|Piapoco]] | [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]] | 1033 | pia |- align=center | [[Baniwa language|Baniwa]] | [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]] | 3460 | kpc |- align=center | [[Arawak language|Locono]] | [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]] | 140 | arw |- align=center | [[Wayuu language|Wayúu]] | [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan]] |170000 |guc |- align=center | [[Warao language|Warao]] | [[Language isolate|(isolate)]] | 18000 |mis |- align=center | [[Pemon language|Pemón]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |30000 |aoc |- align=center | [[Panare language|Panare]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |1200 |pbh |- align=center | [[Ye'kuana language|Yek'uana]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |5000 |mch |- align=center | [[Yukpa language|Yukpa]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |3285 |yup |- align=center | [[Carib language|Carib]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |4450 |kar |- align=center | [[Kapóng language|Akawaio]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |644 |ake |- align=center | [[Japreria language|Japrería]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |91 |jru |- align=center | [[Mapoyo-Yabarana language|Mapoyo]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |2 |mcg |- align=center | [[Mapoyo-Yabarana language|Yawarana]] | [[Cariban languages|Cariban]] |30 |yar |- align=center | [[Hodï language|Hodï]] | [[Nadahup languages|Nadahup]] |750 |yau |- align=center | [[Puinave language|Puinave]] | [[Nadahup languages|Nadahup]] |568 |pui |- align=center | [[Guahibo language|Jivi]] | [[Guahibo language|Guahibo]] |8428 |guh |- align=center | [[Barí language|Barí]] | [[Chibchan languages|Chibcha]] |2000 |mot |- align=center | [[Arutani language|Uruak]] | [[Arutani–Sape languages|Arutani–Sape]] |30 |atx |- align=center | [[Sapé language|Sapé]] | [[Arutani–Sape languages|Arutani–Sape]] |30 |spc |- align=center | [[Yaruro language|Pumé]] | [[Language isolate|(isolate)]] |5420 |yae |- align=center | [[Piaroa language|Piaroa]] | [[Piaroa–Saliban languages|Piaroa–Saliban]] |12200 |pid |- align=center | [[Yanomamö language|Yanomamö]] | [[Yanomaman languages|Yanomami]] |15700 |guu |- align=center | [[Sanumá language|Sanemá]] | [[Yanomaman languages|Yanomami]] |5500 |xsu |- align=center | [[Ninam language|Yanam]] | [[Yanomaman languages|Yanomami]] |100 |shb |- align=center | [[Nheengatu language|Yeral]] | [[Tupi–Guarani languages|Tupi–Guarani]] |435 |yrl |}
== Immigrant languages ==
Languages spoken by immigrants and their descendants are found in Venezuela. The most important are [[Chinese language|Chinese]] (400,000), [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (254,000), [[Italian language|Italian]] (200,000),<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bernasconi|first1=Giulia|title=L’ITALIANO IN VENEZUELA|journal=Italiano LinguaDue|date=2012|issue=2|page=20|doi=10.13130/2037-3597/1921|url=https://www.openaire.eu/search/publication?articleId=doajarticles::e2c6e2d8ae5915079007d321c21defb0|accessdate=22 January 2017|publisher=Università degli Studi di Milano|language=Italian|quote=L'italiano come lingua acquisita o riacquisita è largamente diffuso in Venezuela: recenti studi stimano circa 200.000 studenti di italiano nel Paese}}</ref> [[Arabic language|Arabic]] (110,000), [[German language|German]] (20,000) and [[English language|English]] (20,000).<ref name="Ethnologue">{{cite web|title=Venezuela|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/country/VE|website=Ethnologue|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref>
Some people who live next to the border of [[Brazil]] speak Portuguese. In the areas located near to [[Guyana]] English language is used by some inhabitants, especially on [[Ankoko Island]]. [[Colonia Tovar dialect]], a dialect of [[German language]], is spoken in the [[Colonia Tovar]].
== Languages taught in schools ==
=== English ===
English is a foreign language with a great demand in Venezuela. It is spoken by many academics and professionals and by some members of the middle and high social classes. There is an English language newspaper in Caracas: ''The Daily Journal'', founded in 1946. The use of English arose in part due to the presence of oil companies from English speaking countries (especially from the United States) since the beginning of the 20th century.
English is taught as a compulsory subject in the secondary education and in the ''bachillerato'' for five years. Bachillerato is a segment of secondary education similar to the [[baccalaureat]], [[secondary school]] or American [[high school]] and is divided into two branches: sciences and humanities. According to the syllabus approved by the Venezuelan Ministry of Education in 1986 English language is considered as a tool to communicate with people from other countries and to obtain information in the areas of humanities, technology and science.<ref>Ministerio de Educación: ''Programas de Estudio, Educación Básica, INGLÉS, 7o, 8o, 9o grados''. Caracas: 1986 {{es icon}}</ref> For that reason it is taught using a [[Communicative Language Teaching|Notional Functional Approach]].<ref>Ministerio de Educación: ''Programas de Estudio, Educación Básica, INGLÉS, 7o, 8o, 9o grados''. Caracas: 1986 {{es icon}}</ref> In the bachillerato a [[Structuralism|Structuralistic Approach]] is used. Despite the lines provided by the syllabus, few people learn to speak the language with only the knowledge acquired at school.
In some universities degree programs to train teachers or translators of English language are offered. In the rest of universities English is studied as a compulsory subject to understand texts written in this language.
=== Italian === {{main|Italian language in Venezuela}} In the second half of the twentieth century, more than 300,000 Italians mostly from [[Veneto]] moved to this oil rich country and left -linguistically - many words in the local language. For example, "Ciao" (English: Bye) is now a usual friendly salute in Caracas, not only between [[Italo-Venezuelans]]. There are even expressions in the local young people that mix Italian and Spanish words: "Muérete que chao" is an example.
According to the Italian Embassy in Caracas the "....Italian language teaching is guaranteed by the presence of a consistent number of private Venezuelan schools and institutions, where Italian language courses and Italian literature are active. Other similar courses are organized and sponsored by the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Regional Associations.
The Didactic Office of the General Consulate of Caracas, together with the Embassy, is negotiating an Agreement with the Venezuelan Authorities for the recognition of the Study Diplomas emitted by the Italian School (in Venezuela there is a Civil Association called “Agostino Codazzi” which offers the complete didactic cycle from elementary to high school) so that there can be access to the University system in Venezuela with an Italian high school Diploma.
=== French === [[French language]] is taught as a compulsory subject in the branch of humanities of the ''bachillerato'' or high school for two years. Students learn French grammar in their first year of study, then construct and translate French texts in the second year.
In some universities degree programs to train teachers or translators of French language are offered.
=== Latin and Greek === In [[Venezuela]] Latin is taught as a compulsory subject in the branch of humanities of the high school for two years. Students learn Latin grammar in their first year, then construct and translate Latin texts in the second year.<ref>Duque Arellano, José Gonzalo [http://servidor-opsu.tach.ula.ve/ascen_acro/duque_j/latin/capitulo2.pdf Pertinencia y vigencia del latín en la enseñanza de la lengua española, en las áreas de la morfología y de la sintaxis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227060653/http://servidor-opsu.tach.ula.ve/ascen_acro/duque_j/latin/capitulo2.pdf |date=2008-02-27 }}; ''Universidad de los Andes'' {{es icon}}</ref>
At university level, the [[University of the Andes, Venezuela|University of the Andes]] offers a degree program for ''Letras Mención Lengua y Literaturas Clásicas'' (''Classical Languages and Literatures''). In this program (the only one of its type in Venezuela), the students learn Latin, [[Ancient Greek]] and the literature of both languages for five years.<ref>[http://loe.cnu.gov.ve/ver_info_carrera.php?cod_carrera=349&cod_area=7&cod_subarea=22 Detalle de la Carrera: "Letras Mención Lengua y Literaturas Clasicas"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209164949/http://loe.cnu.gov.ve/ver_info_carrera.php?cod_carrera=349&cod_area=7&cod_subarea=22 |date=2008-02-09 }}; ''CNU-OPSU: Oportunidades de Estudio de Educación Superior en Venezuela'' {{es icon}}</ref> In other Venezuelan universities, Latin is a compulsory subject of the program for ''Letras'' (''Hispanic Literature'') and ''Educación, mención: Castellano y Literatura'' (''Education of Spanish language and Hispanic Literature'').
Latin and [[Koine Greek]] are also taught in [[Seminary|Roman Catholic seminaries]].
== Sources ==
<references/>
== See also ==
* [[Italian language in Venezuela]] * [[Venezuelan Spanish]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/47.8.4.43|47.8.4.43]] ([[User talk:47.8.4.43|talk]]): Rv -- too specific, may not be hard limits for some people. original definition is better. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=August 2013}} In [[BDSM]], '''limits''' refer to issues that participants in a [[Play (BDSM)|play]] [[BDSM#Scenes|scene]] or dynamic feel strongly about, usually referring to prohibited activities. Participants typically [[Consent (BDSM)#Negotiation|negotiate]] an outline of what activities will and will not take place. The participants describe what they desire, do not desire, will and will not tolerate, including the determination of limits. For example, it is common to set a [[safeword]] and to establish certain types of play as prohibited.
The BDSM usage of the terminology "limits" derives from the concept of "off limits", the idea of limiting a scene to a specific set of activities, and the limitations (in terms of interest, as well as physical and emotional tolerance) of the participants.
==Setting limits== Both [[Top (BDSM)|dominant]]s and [[Bottom (BDSM)|submissive]]s can set limits. Limits can be agreed to verbally or they can be incorporated into a formal contract. Sometimes the participants engage in a formal conversation about limits and boundaries; this is referred to as [[Consent (BDSM)#Negotiation|negotiation]]. Other couples discuss their likes and dislikes in a similar manner to "[[Vanilla sex|Vanilla]]" relationships.
==="No limits"=== Some partners choose not to set limits. This is commonly seen in [[Master/slave (BDSM)|total power exchange]] dynamics, [[Consent (BDSM)#Consensual non-consent|consensual non-consent]], and [[edgeplay]]. Whether or not this type of arrangement is considered "[[safe, sane and consensual]]" is a matter of some controversy in BDSM communities, those favoring the approach pointing that limits are either wishful thoughts which can never be reliably enforced, or sometimes, just deceptions in order to find acceptance by society.
==Types of limits== The terminology varies slightly across different local communities and Internet forums. However, there are general usages recognized across most BDSM populations.
===Hard limit=== A hard limit is something that must not be done. Violating a hard limit is often considered a just cause for ending a scene or even a relationship. Examples include “[[feces|scat]] is a hard limit for me” or “I have a back injury, so striking on the back is a hard limit”.
===Soft limit=== A soft limit is something that a person hesitates about or places strict conditions on, but for which they may still give informed consent. An action could be prohibited except under specific circumstances or an area of discomfort that someone wishes to avoid. Soft limits can also include actions that require a cautious approach or — while somewhat appealing — still generate an uncomfortable amount of apprehension in one or more partners.
===Requirement limit=== A requirement limit, or must-limit, is something without which one or more partners will not participate in the scene. Examples include “lots of hair pulling is a must-limit for me” or “if you’re going to flog me, I’ll need lots of [[Aftercare (BDSM)|aftercare]].”
===Time limit=== A time limit is a set time period for which an activity or temporary relationship takes place. This is most common for [[BDSM#Scenes|scenes]] and casual [[Play (BDSM)|play]].
Some couples practice time limitations for relationships. They can be used to set time limits on phases of relationships, such as training or consideration.
==See also== *[[Glossary of BDSM]]
== Further reading == * [[Gloria G. Brame]], William D. Brame, and Jon Jacobs. ''Different Loving: An Exploration of the World of Sexual Dominance and Submission.'' New York: Villard Books, 1993. {{ISBN|0-679-40873-8}}. * Philip Miller and Molly Devon, ''Screw the Roses, Send Me the Thorns: The Romance and Sexual Sorcery of Sadomasochism.'' Mystic Rose Books, 1995. {{ISBN|0-9645960-0-8}}.
== External links == * [http://www.tes.org The Eulenspiegel Society]
{{BDSM}}
[[Category:BDSM terminology]]

{{Expand French|date=January 2011|Louis Notari}} '''Louis Notari''' ([[Monaco]], 1879-1961) was the pioneer of Monégasque [[literature]]. He wrote in the [[French language|French]] and [[Monégasque language|Monégasque]] languages.
==Principal writings==
He wrote the text of the [[Hymne Monégasque|Monaco national anthem]] and he is considered as the first writer in Monégasque; before him, there was just [[oral literature]]. He wrote three books.
*''A legenda de Santa Devota''/''Santa Devota'' (1927) -about the legend of [[Saint Devota]]. *''Bülüghe munegasche'' (1941). *''Quelques notes sur les traditions de Monaco'' (1960).
Notari's writing in Monégasque has led to a veritable flowering of literature published in the language. A grammar and a dictionary by [[Louis Frolla]] and numerous other works, including by [[Georges Franzi]], [[Louis Barral]] and Suzanne Simone (dictionary) [[Louis Canis]], [[Jules Soccal]], Lazare Sauvaigo and Robert Buisson, combine to allow this small country's own language to take its visible and permanent place among the other Romance languages.
However, while a substantial proportion of Notari's work was religious in inspiration, Monégasque is probably unique among the Romance languages in that it possesses, as yet, no Bible translation.
==Former fascist sympathies==
In his researches in Monégasque identity, Notari got in touch in the 1930s with Italian academics sustaining regional languages for a Latin federation pledged to the [[Italian fascism|fascist Italian]] government.<ref>''Un rocher bien occupé, [[Monaco]] pendant la guerre 1939-1945'', [[Pierre Abramovici]], Seuil, Paris, 2001,</ref> In this way, he wrote a few poems celebrating [[Benito Mussolini]].<ref>Annales du comté de Nice (1934-1935), FM17-Bibliothèque Notari (Monaco)</ref>
In the [[post-War]] era, however, any fascist sympathies which Notari may once have held were not stressed.
==Personal legacy== The decision by the late [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Prince Rainier III]] to sponsor Monégasque teachers in local schools owed much to the groundwork in promoting Monégasque which writers such as Notari and others laid. Louis Notari was also prominent in [[civil engineering]] in the Principality, and was noted for his work on Monaco's renowned [[Jardin Exotique de Monaco|exotic garden]], which annually hosts large numbers of visitors from many countries.
A street in the suburb of [[La Condamine]], Monaco, is named after Louis Notari. A library, the [[Bibliothèque Louis Notari]], which serves as the national [[copyright]] library for Monaco, is also named after him.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Notari, Louis}} [[Category:Monegasque writers]] [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:National anthem writers]] [[Category:French-language writers]]
{{Monaco-bio-stub}} {{Europe-writer-stub}}
